p: By contrast, MERS begins with pyrexia, cough, pharyngitis, muscle aches, and joints pain, succeeded by dyspnoea, and fast progress to pneumonia in 7Â days, frequently warrants ventilatory assistance [42]. Abnormal chest X-rays are more prevalent than in SARS cases, with up to 89% of cases requiring ICU care, unlike SARS, the clinical pattern of MERS is more severe in immunocompromised cases and regularly mild in patients with no comorbidities [14], [43]. Additionally, up to 72% of MERS patients likely to manifest with comorbidities [44]. Correspondingly, RT-PCR is warranted for MERS-CoV confirmation and ruling out differentials like H1N1 and Influenza A and B [36], [45].
